video.title: APIs for Beginners - How to use an API (Full Course / Tutorial)
video.description:
What is an API? Learn all about APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) in this full tutorial for beginners. You will learn what APIs do, why APIs exist, and the many benefits of APIs. APIs are used all the time in programming and web development so it is important to understand how to use them.

You will also get hands-on experience with a few popular web APIs. As long as you know the absolute basics of coding and the web, you'll have no problem following along.

🔗 Course Notes: https://github.com/craigsdennis/intro-to-apis-course/blob/master/course-notes.md

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️

⭐️ Unit 1 - What is an API
⌨️ Video 1 - Welcome (0:00:00)
⌨️ Video 2 - Defining Interface (0:03:57)
⌨️ Video 3 - Defining API (0:07:51)
⌨️ Video 4 - Remote APIs (0:12:55)
⌨️ Video 5 - How the web works (0:17:04)
⌨️ Video 6 - RESTful API Constraint Scavenger Hunt (0:22:00)

⭐️ Unit 2 - Exploring APIs
⌨️ Video 1 - Exploring an API online (0:27:36)
⌨️ Video 2 - Using an API from the command line  (0:44:30)
⌨️ Video 3 - Using Postman to explore APIs (0:53:56)
⌨️ Video 4 - Please please Mr. Postman (1:03:33)
⌨️ Video 5 - Using Helper Libraries (JavaScript) (1:14:41)
⌨️ Video 6 - Using Helper Libraries (Python) (1:24:40)

⭐️ Unit 3 - Using APIs
⌨️ Video 1 - Introducing the project (1:34:18)
⌨️ Video 2 - Flask app  (1:36:07)
⌨️ Video 3 - Dealing with API Limits (1:50:00)
⌨️ Video 4 - JavaScript Single Page Application (1:54:27)
⌨️ Video 5 - Moar JavaScript and Recap (2:07:53)
⌨️ Video 6 - Review (2:18:03)

🎥 Course created by Craig Dennis, Developer Educator at Twilio
🐦 Craig on Twitter: @craigsdennis

Check out free Postman programs for students and educators to help you learn more about APIs: https://www.postman.com/company/student-program/

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Chris
topLevelComment.text: 'Education isn't meant to be binged' - since hearing this I have put thought into my brain and am learning way faster than I ever thought possible. I went from learning 1 thing at time in big monolithic chunks that put me to sleep and had me questioning my commitment - to much smaller chunks of video not longer than 10 to 15 minutes and a much larger variety of subjects and speakers to keep me fresh - much more energy using this approach. And it doesn't worry me to on-board a subject - just work it into the daily watch list - if there are too many of them just prioritise the ones you definately want to watch or shorten the daily watch time to fit them all in. So easy.

topLevelComment.author: Ricardo Penders
topLevelComment.text:
Yeah it's in the header where you can put some obscure code that the user doesn't see or has any idea of that it's there, you should know at least the basics of what's happening on the background of the API that you're using so you're able to recognize if the API is safe to use or that the API is giving unauthorized access to the server or the client.
Keep using API's the way you do and it's a matter of time that it goes horribly wrong, it's not a question of if it happens anymore because nowadays bad things happen to everyone who's doing things online.
You have been warned, what you do with this information is totally up to you.
One thing that I wouldn't teach or dare to say online is that you can use API's without knowing what happens in the background, that's bad advice so if you read this comment please don't listen to this guy, he may be able to use the API's but he has no idea what the API is capable of and what it can do without you even knowing or seeing anything that the API may be doing to your system or the server making it even more dangerous because if it sits somewhere on the server it can infect many computers, phones etc. and at the time that people finally begin to suspect that there's something wrong with their system it's already too late, who knows what happens if you don't have any knowledge of the inner workings of the API.

topLevelComment.author: Ricardo Penders
topLevelComment.text:
That's a very big security risk you're taking if you only use an API and you don't know how the API is working on the background, API's are the new thing that hackers are interested in because of the lack of security of the API's.
The first thing that I want to know of any API that I'm going to use is how it works in the background or at least how I can make use of the API in a safe way keeping hackers out.

topLevelComment.author: Christoff
topLevelComment.text:
Really good and clear tutorial. Well paced and explained. Just a note to a few people: when you get to the Twilio section, if your mobile number is based outside the US&Canada, the Twilio API will shift the MediaURL value into the BODY as plain text. It still gets sent by the API and received by the mobile device but is received as a link on the mobile device. Therefore the next stage when you try to GET the gif you have just sent will not work. Took me ages to work this out! 
*** It would be really useful to add a flag / annotation to the video at this point so people outside North America do not think they have made a mistake and lose time / give up ***

topLevelComment.author: Jeff Cross
topLevelComment.text: Obviously 1mil+ views can't be wrong but unfortunately, I gave up 30minutes in. The keyboard shortcuts were hard to follow but I managed. The killer though, the steps you use for authenticating via Postman into the API no longer exist in current versions of Postman and, being a beginner, I simply don't know what to do. Then the method you used to set environment variables no longer exists (environment variables do exist but have changed.) Unfortunately, you don't really explain what you are doing as much as just "do this." When I can't do this due to GUI changes in Postman, I am stuck. I found myself floundering so much I am giving up and moving to a more current version of Postman/API training.

topLevelComment.text: i hear abstraction so often but can never understand what it means practically. what is abstraction, kindly explain in simple practical terms. Thanks in advance.

replies.author: Julian Julian
replies.text:
An abstraction is like an overview of something that is easier to work with, instead of details. 

For example we can consider languages like Java an abstraction of machine code/byte code/whatever. If we are writing programs we don't need to know the details of what the Java code looks like when it is compiled. Writing Java "abstracts away" us having to write 0s and 1s ourselves.

Basically I am trying to create the teacher that is there for you that can help you walk through things together, even when they get challenging.

Again, I realize my style is not for everyone, and I do hope you find what you are looking for! If you do, share it here so others in your boat can benefit.

Thanks again for your feedback!

topLevelComment.author: BeaverDono
topLevelComment.text:
Just going to leave this comment here for Windows 10 users.. (03/18/2022)

READ the GitHub course notes for Twilio section! You need to setup/tweak a environment for yourself to send a text message to yourself. Twilio at the moment won't let you "show" your Auth Token so you'll have to go into your account information to dig it out. 

If you had issues like I did just using the curl command, you might be running into Execution Policy issue. I ended up changing it from Restricted to ByPass to get it to work correctly.

Next, get rid of the "\" at the end of the code. If you are working in a PowerShell and sending that code, it'll just pop up resolve host errors. 

Happy programming peeps!

topLevelComment.author: Daniel Black
topLevelComment.text:
Here I am, employed as a developer, watching a video that purports to be for beginners, and it's a great video so far. One of the things I love about approaches like this is that, especially for developers like me who just picked up some crap over time and am doing stuff with it, there are lots of fundamentals that slip through those autodidactic cracks. For instance, I _know_ what "statelessness" means generally, but then at around 23:30 Craig explains not only clearly but completely enough for the context--with no extraneous details.

Nice work.

I find that odd since I could send messages via the UI (I feel I might be doing something wrong) but I followed the instructions to the letter. 2. I went through the course notes and everything. did my own research - setup a virtual env on linux to parse curl statements and still it is a bit overwhelming at times. (to be continued)....

topLevelComment.author: Jordan Belfort
topLevelComment.text: What a misleading intro. "All you need to know is how to code 'hello world'". Yeah, no. That last hour of that tut is a complete pain in the a.. if you are not at least an intermediate JS or Python user. That's btw a recurring theme in your tuts: The first hour tends to be good; you take time to explain things clearly. And then suddenly for the last 30-60 minutes it totally goes to crap with you rushing through things without any explanations or even stating WHY you are doing what you are doing (that last part is actually the most important point!).

replies.author: Craig Dennis
replies.text: Also if you have specific issues on things that were hard to understand, I'd love to add them to the notes.

replies.author: Craig Dennis
replies.text:
Thanks for the feedback Jordan, I appreciate it. This is definitely a hard line to walk and I'm sorry I missed the mark for you. I was definitely trying to not get into web frameworks and just focus on the parts where we were using the API directly. I did try to do a repeat on every video where I went through what I was doing, but I agree that I am asking the learner to ignore a lot of what is going on. There is complexity that arises from the asynchronous nature of JavaScript and maybe I rushed through that too much.

There is a delicate balance to strike as even though the pre-requisites are light, I will also get feedback that I shouldn't be explaining what a variable is, or what branching does, or even Python spacing syntax. I do hope to find some way to solve this problem, but it is definitely hard to do correctly in a synchronous video.

I do appreciate your feedback and will strive to make this better in the future!

replies.author: Craig Dennis
replies.text:
Thanks for the feedback. Sorry this format didn't work for you, over my time producing beginner content, I've found that it does in fact help engagement and confidence for a majority of learners. That said, I know it's not for everyone, but nothing is. I do hope you find the course you are looking for, and thanks again for the feedback.

By animation puns, did you mean the pause menus? Also want to make sure you can see the video section titles in the comments. That should help you locate where you were.

replies.author: Rich Lorenzo
replies.text:
I've only ever run cURL commands from a work computer (Mac) so I ran into some trouble on my personal PC. Here's what I learned to get it to work: 
1. Replace all of the \ with ` (that's the backtick character not an apostrophe) 
2. In PowerShell I had to run the following command first in order to avoid the "ambiguous character" error: Remove-item alias:curl

replies.author: Craig Dennis
replies.text:
Hi Paval, thanks for the feedback! Not sure if this is a rhetorical question or not, but I figured I'd give it a shot! Over time I've found that taking the time to breakdown complicated concepts is well worth it. It can help uncover previous misconceptions as well as solidify knowledge.
I'm aware that there will people who find it too much, but, the audience for this is beginners. I definitely tried to explain that in the opening, so as to not waste people's time.
I'm not sure where specifically you see me apologizing for complexity, but would welcome that feedback!
Thanks for reaching out and sharing your feelings!
